com.adobe.webserver.handlers

Class HTTPMethodHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.adobe.webserver.handlers.HTTPMethodHandler
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GETHandler, POSTHandler

    public abstract class HTTPMethodHandler
extends Object
    It Is the base class for all Handlers for specific HTTP Methods It provides some very basic functionalities used by all handlers. All Implementors of this class must ensure that they don't close the three input/output Streams (which are protected parameters of this class) They can only use this streams to read and write to them. they must implement the handle method(which is a abstract method)
    Author:
    KHEMKA

    • Method Detail

      • getHeader

        protected HashMap<String,String> getHeader()
                                    throws IOException,
                                           IllegalRequestException
        reads header from client and stores it into a HashMap.
        Returns:
        the HashMap of key value pairs of header
        Throws:
        IOException - when read/write error occurs
        IllegalRequestException - if an invalid header is sent

      • decodeURI

        protected String decodeURI(String requestURI)
                    throws IOException
        URI passed in request-line is generally encoded. for processing request this must be decoded This method decodes such URI.
        Parameters:
        requestURI - the uri to decode
        Returns:
        decoded uri. null if it can't decode.
        Throws:
        IOException - when some read write occurs

      • handle

        public abstract void handle(String requestURI)
                     throws IOException,
                            IllegalRequestException
        this method reads header/ analyses header and responds accordingly. don't close the streams .
        Parameters:
        requestURI - the request-uri in request-line
        Throws:
        IOException - if some read/write error occurs
        IllegalRequestException - when request is not properly formed
